I think It is better to change Elbow -> Arm to be more consistent to the description given in this [link](http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Models#Physical_Properties).

content.raw:
I think we will probably need an easy way to change between the model used in Simspark (the "fake" NAO in your link) and the model with the real robot's dimensions. Each of them will probably have different joint / link quantities, names and dimensions.

I think we probably need one header file like this for each of them. The question is what's the best way to switch among them. Any thoughts? Perhaps a parameter in the plugin?
content.html:
I think we will probably need an easy way to change between the model used in Simspark (the "fake" NAO in your link) and the model with the real robot's dimensions. Each of them will probably have different joint / link quantities, names and dimensions.

I think we probably need one header file like this for each of them. The question is what's the best way to switch among them. Any thoughts? Perhaps a parameter in the plugin?

content.raw: The ElbowYaw or ArmYaw, which are used in both fake NAO and this model to rotate the arm is commanded by simspark and Robocup agents with ae3. ElbowRoll is also commanded with ae4. So the definition of ae3 and ae4 should be swapped for both hands in Preceptor and Effector map.
content.html: The ElbowYaw or ArmYaw, which are used in both fake NAO and this model to rotate the arm is commanded by simspark and Robocup agents with ae3. ElbowRoll is also commanded with ae4. So the definition of ae3 and ae4 should be swapped for both hands in Preceptor and Effector map.

Left -> Right?

And does the plane direction matter here? Shouldn't they be pointing on opposite directions for some calculations?
content.html:
Left -> Right?

And does the plane direction matter here? Shouldn't they be pointing on opposite directions for some calculations?

content.raw: The plane direction does not matter for calculating intersections. Plus, if you use the Ax + By + Cz + D = 0 plane equation, the normal does not have a direction.
content.html: The plane direction does not matter for calculating intersections. Plus, if you use the Ax + By + Cz + D = 0 plane equation, the normal does not have a direction.

content.raw: I see, ok. I was wondering if you'd use it with the `PointAbovePlane` or `ClipPlaneLine` functions from pull request #14, for which the direction matters. Maybe it doesn't hurt to have them facing opposite directions?
content.html: I see, ok. I was wondering if you'd use it with the PointAbovePlane or ClipPlaneLine functions from pull request #14, for which the direction matters. Maybe it doesn't hurt to have them facing opposite directions?
